title: 'Outrageously high' credit card rates continue to rise
text:
Official interest rates may be close to zero but interest costs on credit cards are pushing even higher to nearly 25 per cent – almost 14 times the rate of inflation.

Fiona Guthrie, chief executive of the nation’s peak body for debt advice, Financial Counselling Australia, describes the costs as “outrageously high” and the “number one” problem for debt.

Credit card fees have on average jumped by six basis points and rates range from 6.64 per cent to nearly 25 per cent for shopping or paying bills, according to analysis by Canstar, which monitors fees and rates.

Many cards also have annual fees. For example, Qantas American Express Ultimate Card's annual fee is $450 while Virgin Australia Velocity Flyer Card’s annual fee is $129. Both cards have a purchase rate of 20.7 per cent for borrowers who do not repay in full within the interest-free period.

They are difficult to manage. It means people are trapped in a cycle of debt. — Fiona Guthrie, Financial Counselling Australia

Using a credit card to withdraw money from a bank, or buy foreign currency on an overseas trip, can cost around 26 per cent in interest rate charges, with some providers recently increasing these rates by more than 100 basis points.
description: Personal loans or finding a cheaper credit card are recommended for big earners rotating debt.
